description: Learned borrowing from Ancient Greek πολυμαθής (polumathḗs, “having learnt much”), first attested in 1624. From πολύς (polús, “much”) + μανθάνω (manthánō, “to learn”). Compare opsimath, philomath, polyhistor, polymathic, polymathist, and polymathy.

entries.meaning: A person with extraordinarily broad and comprehensive knowledge.
examples: To be thought and held Polumathes and Polihistors.
